newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russia 1997 securities yields under 20 pct - Dubinin.
newsitem.headline: Russia 1997 securities yields under 20 pct - Dubinin.

text.p: Yields on Russian state securities will likely fall below 20 percent next year from an average of 38-40 percent, the head of the central bank said on Wednesday.

"The situation will normalise next year when, with inflation at about 12 percent, we intend to pay 17, 18 or maybe 19 percent on state borrowings," Sergei Dubinin told a meeting of Russia's top financiers.
He said he saw yields on securities by the end of 1997 at four to five percentage points above the level of inflation, which he predicted would be 11-12 percent for the year.
Dubinin said that M2, a broad measure of monetary supply, would grow in 1997 at a rate similar to 1996.
"The growth of M2 was 35 percent in 1996, and we expect the same in 1997, 34-36 percent," he said.
He said securities yields were expected to start slipping already by the end of this year, but said there would be no government orders for this to happen.
"We do not plan any government resolutions ordering quarterly yield cuts next year, but the fact is that the trend will be towards lower yields," Dubinin said.
In summer this year the government issued a resolution, ordering gradual cuts in T-bill yields.

The 1997 draft budget provides for a fall in the issue of government securities, which, combined with a yield fall, is part of the govenrment's efforts to tempt cash away from T-bills and bonds into the production sphere of the economy.
